I will restate your question to ask whether having test cases makes
debuggers obsolete, since there is nothing intrinsically special about
JUnit beyond the fact that it kicks off test cases for you, provides
validation APIs and presents the result. The test cases themselves
interact with your objects under test to ensure that they are providing
their services correctly and are the important part. 

The answer to your questions is probably 'no' unless you are lucky
enough to have placed enough logging statements directly in a failing
area of code so that all the state information required to determine the
cause of the problem is available. 

A test case can tell you that an area of code has failed but it cannot
directly tell you why. You have to determine that indirectly through
observation of a combination of:
1) The test that failed and the output from the results (actual vs.
expected or stack trace)
2) Any additional output from logging. 
3) The external state of the system under test after the test has
completed
4) the internal state of the system during and after the test has
completed

Number 4 above implies a debugger and is usually the most direct,
powerful and deterministic approach. 

^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
Mike Silverstein	
SilverMark, Inc.
The object testing company			
http://www.javatesting.com
